verses.text: Do not rely on your wealth, nor say, 'I have enough.'
verses.comment: The original Hebrew emphasizes the fleeting nature of wealth and warns against putting trust in material things. See also Jesus' teachings on laying up treasures in heaven.

verses.text: Do not follow your desires or your strength, pursuing the desires of your heart.
verses.comment: Echoes the wisdom tradition warning against unchecked passions. Verse anticipates the call to self-denial for the sake of holiness.

verses.text: Do not say, 'Who can overpower me?' For the Lord will surely punish you.
verses.comment: This verse warns against pride in one's own power. God alone has ultimate authority—compare Christ’s parable of the rich fool.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I have sinned, and nothing has happened to me,' for the Lord is patient, but he will not let you go unpunished.
verses.comment: The delay of punishment is an expression of God’s mercy, giving space for repentance, not a sign He overlooks sin.

verses.text: Do not be so sure of forgiveness that you add sin to sin.
verses.comment: A key text against presumption. True repentance includes a commitment to avoid sin, not just relying on God’s mercy. This points to the call to ongoing conversion and penance.

verses.text: Do not say, 'His compassion is great; he will forgive the multitude of my sins.' For with him is mercy, but also anger, and his wrath falls on sinners.
verses.comment: God's mercy is real, but so is his justice. Familiar themes anticipate the New Testament balance of justice and mercy unveiled in Christ.

verses.text: Do not delay to turn to the Lord, and do not put it off from day to day; for suddenly the wrath of the Lord will come, and in the time of punishment you will be destroyed.
verses.comment: This verse warns against procrastinating repentance. Immediate conversion is essential—a theme strongly underlined by Jesus.

verses.text: Do not trust in dishonest riches, for they will not benefit you on the day of calamity.
verses.comment: Material wealth gained by unrighteous means brings divine judgment. Compare Jesus’ teaching on true treasure.

verses.text: Do not be blown about by every wind, nor walk along every path. So do not double-mindedly walk in ways not your own.
verses.comment: This verse encourages steadfastness and spiritual integrity, not wavering or following every trend.

verses.text: Be firm in your understanding, and let your speech be consistent.
verses.comment: Integrity in word and belief is fundamental; compare Jesus’ counsel to let your 'yes' be 'yes.'

verses.text: Be quick to listen, but slow in answering; if you understand a matter, keep silent.
verses.comment: Echoes the wisdom exhortation to humility and patience in conversation.

verses.text: If you have insight, answer your neighbor; but if not, put your hand over your mouth.
verses.comment: Similar in spirit to the Proverbs, encouraging wisdom, humility, and restraint in speech.

verses.text: Honor and shame come from speaking, and the tongue of mortals can bring downfall.
verses.comment: The power of speech is a major biblical theme—uncontrolled speech can bring judgment.

verses.text: Do not be called a slanderer, nor lay traps with your tongue; for shame comes to the thief, and harsh condemnation to the double-tongued.
verses.comment: God's judgment against slander and deceit is consistent across the biblical witness. Judicious speech reflects a mature faith.

verses.text: Do not be ignorant in great or small matters.
verses.comment: The call to wisdom in all matters points to the comprehensive nature of God's expectation, recalling Christ’s parable of the talents—a call to diligence and stewardship in all aspects of life.
